title.value: Towards contrast-agnostic soft segmentation of the spinal cord
title.justification: This fits with the primary focus and goal of the research described in the paper.
title.quote: Towards contrast-agnostic soft segmentation of the spinal cord

extractions.description: The paper presents a method for contrast-agnostic soft segmentation of the spinal cord using MRI images. The method leverages a dataset consisting of multiple contrasts and introduces a novel pipeline for generating soft ground truth segmented images. This pipeline includes preprocessing of data, dataset augmentation, and a unique loss function centered around regression (specifically, adaptive wing loss). The proposed model is tested against state-of-the-art methods and demonstrates superior performance in reducing cross-sectional area (CSA) variability across different contrasts and shows remarkable generalization capabilities to unseen data, including images with various spinal pathologies.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments with different datasets, training deep learning models, and evaluating their performance against baselines and state-of-the-art methods.
type.quote: We evaluated our model against state-of-the-art methods and performed ablation studies involving different GT mask types, loss functions, and contrast-specific models.

name.justification: The research focuses on improving spinal cord segmentation in MRI images, which is a relevant problem in the field of computer vision, a subfield of artificial intelligence focused on training computers to interpret and understand the visual world.
name.quote: Spinal cord segmentation is clinically relevant, notably to compute cross-sectional area (CSA) for the diagnosis and monitoring of atrophy in multiple sclerosis (MS), spinal cord injury (SCI), and in characterizing spinal cord compression.

name.justification: The paper specifically deals with segmented images from MRI scans and aims to improve clinical imaging techniques.
name.quote: We present a deep learning-based method that produces soft segmentations of the spinal cord.

name.justification: The primary model introduced in the paper is the UNet architecture adapted for producing soft segmentations of the spinal cord in various MRI contrasts.
name.quote: Using the Spine Generic Public Database of healthy participants (n = 267; contrasts = 6), we first generated participant-wise soft ground truth (GT) by averaging the binary segmentations across all 6 contrasts. These soft GT, along with aggressive data augmentation and a regression-based loss function, were then used to train a UNet model for spinal cord segmentation.

name.justification: The dataset used in the study is from the Spine Generic Public Database which provides diverse and multi-contrast MRI images of the spinal cord.
name.quote: We used the Spine Generic Public Database2 (Multi-Subject) (Cohen-Adad et al., 2021a) consisting of 267 healthy participants scanned across multiple MRI vendors (Siemens, GE and Philips) and scanner models.

name.justification: The researchers used the MONAI framework, which is a deep learning library specifically targeted at medical imaging tasks.
name.quote: These augmentation methods are readily implemented in MONAI (Jorge Cardoso et al., 2022).

name.justification: PyTorch Lightning was used to train the neural network models in the study.
name.quote: All the models were trained using the MONAI (Jorge Cardoso et al., 2022) and PyTorch Lightning frameworks on a single 48 GB NVIDIA A6000 GPU.

name.justification: SCT was used for the spinal cord image processing tasks like segmentation and registration.
name.quote: The GT soft segmentations are generated by averaging 6 different contrasts (T1w, T2w, T2*w, MT-on, GRE-T1w and DWI). For each participant and contrast, the spinal cord is segmented using SCTâ€™s sct deepseg sc to generate a binary segmentation.
